You can use vSphere Fault Tolerance (FT) for most mission critical virtual machines. FT provides continuous availability for such a virtual machine by creating and maintaining another VM that is identical and continuously available to replace it in the event of a failover situation. [Read more]

questions.question_text:
An administrator is NOT able to enable ESXi secure boot.
What is a possible cause of this issue?

choices.B: ESXi is using Trusted Platform Module version 1.2.
choices.D: ESXi is using Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI).

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
This is a tricky question which can only be answered by way of elimination. TPM 1.2 is a minimum requirement for 6.5 I think whereas 6.7 started supporting TPM 2.0. Since all other answers refer to version 7.0 or UEFI they can't be the reason for potential issues.

I think this link might add some insite. Talking about how TPM 2.0 is requred.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.security.doc/GUID-10F7022C-DBE1-47A2-BD86-3840C6955057.html

Selected Answer: D
Quick Boot reduces the host reboot time during remediation. Before you enable Quick Boot, you must ensure that the ESXi host is compatible with the feature.
By default, Quick Boot is turned off.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere-lifecycle-manager.doc/GUID-472964C3-70F3-4B83-8B1E-6C7CB4906DF8.html

Selected Answer: D
Using Quick Boot is supported with a limited set of hardware platforms, drivers, and is not supported on ESXi hosts that use TPM or passthru devices. For more information about a host compatibility to Quick Boot option, see the following KB Article: https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/52477.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.update_manager.doc/GUID-3BE855BA-BC43-4133-A493-6AFB30B461B3.html#GUID-3BE855BA-BC43-4133-A493-6AFB30B461B3

Which remediation setting is supported only on select hardware platforms?

Selected Answer: B
You use the VM Storage Policies interface to create a storage policy. When you define the policy, you specify various storage requirements for applications that run on the virtual machines. You can also use storage policies to request specific data services, such as caching or replication, for virtual disks.

questions.question_text: Which feature can be used to specify data services for virtual disks, such as caching or replication?
Which two components are core to vSphere? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: A and C

The two core components of vSphere are VMware ESXi™ and VMware vCenter Server®. ESXi is the hypervisor on which you create and run virtual machines. vCenter Server is a service that acts as a central administrator for ESXi hosts that are connected on a network. With vCenter Server, you can pool and manage the resources of multiple hosts. vCenter Server allows you to monitor and manage your physical and virtual infrastructure.

Selected Answer: AC
A and C

ESXi and vCenter are core components
